channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Incarcerated people who helped fight wildfires struggle to build a career post-prison
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Royal Ramey, the co-founder and CEO of the Forestry and Fire Recruitment Program, about the pathway for formerly incarcerated firefighters to build careers in the field.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Royal Ramey, the co-founder and CEO of the Forestry and Fire Recruitment Program, about the pathway for formerly incarcerated firefighters to build careers in the field.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Fink

item.title: Back-to-back shark attacks leave 4 people injured in Texas and Florida
item.description: An abnormally high number of people were bitten by sharks in coastal waters over the span of a day that began on July 4. Upticks in shark attacks alone are not cause for concern, an expert says.
item.content:encoded:
An abnormally high number of people were bitten by sharks in coastal waters over the span of a day that began on July 4. Upticks in shark attacks alone are not cause for concern, an expert says.

(Image credit: Texas Department of Public Safety)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: North Koreans got jobs at Fortune 500 companies to fund the nuclear weapons program
item.description: The U.S. government and private sector are trying to solve a thorny problem. North Korean IT workers and hackers are infiltrating Fortune 500 companies to fund the regime's nuclear weapons program.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. government and private sector are trying to solve a thorny problem. North Korean IT workers and hackers are infiltrating Fortune 500 companies to fund the regime's nuclear weapons program.
item.dc:creator: Jenna McLaughlin

item.title: Why are IUDs still such a mystery to women? Look at funding, doctors and politics
item.description: IUDs are a safe and reliable form of birth control, but many people struggle to get simple answers about the device. NPR’s Ailsa Chang talks with Mia Armstrong-Lopez, who wrote about this for Slate.
item.content:encoded: IUDs are a safe and reliable form of birth control, but many people struggle to get simple answers about the device. NPR’s Ailsa Chang talks with Mia Armstrong-Lopez, who wrote about this for Slate.
item.dc:creator: Gurjit Kaur

item.title: Who is backing Biden? We're keeping track
item.description: NPR is tracking elected Democrats who have weighed in on whether President Biden should remain in the race for re-election.
item.content:encoded:
NPR is tracking elected Democrats who have weighed in on whether President Biden should remain in the race for re-election.

(Image credit: SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jeongyoon Han

item.title: California aid volunteers prepare for a crisis as migrants cross during heatwaves
item.description: The San Diego sector is where most undocumented border crossings are occurring as temperatures rise. The result is migrants crossing through more remote, dangerous and even deadly parts of the border.
item.content:encoded: The San Diego sector is where most undocumented border crossings are occurring as temperatures rise. The result is migrants crossing through more remote, dangerous and even deadly parts of the border.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Garsd

item.title: A look at Jordan Bardella, the far-right 28-year-old who could be France's next PM
item.description: The young far-right politician Jordan Bardella could become France's next prime minister. At only 28, he’s free of political baggage, but some say he lacks real job — and life — experience.
item.content:encoded: The young far-right politician Jordan Bardella could become France's next prime minister. At only 28, he’s free of political baggage, but some say he lacks real job — and life — experience.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: Artificial intelligence web crawlers are running amok
item.description: Artificial intelligence tech companies are refusing to abide by internet protocol when it comes to scraping data. Their ravenous scavenging behavior is upending the basic rules of the internet.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence tech companies are refusing to abide by internet protocol when it comes to scraping data. Their ravenous scavenging behavior is upending the basic rules of the internet.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: More students with disabilities are facing discrimination in schools
item.description: The Department of Education has received a record number of discrimination complaints, including from families of students with disabilities. Some families are waiting months, even years, for help.
item.content:encoded: The Department of Education has received a record number of discrimination complaints, including from families of students with disabilities. Some families are waiting months, even years, for help.
item.dc:creator: Jonaki Mehta

item.title: Cambodia's difficult journey to get stolen sculptures back from the Met
item.description: Fourteen stolen sculptures are back in Cambodia after New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art agreed to return them. Thousands of historical artworks are thought to have been trafficked out of Colombia.
item.content:encoded: Fourteen stolen sculptures are back in Cambodia after New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art agreed to return them. Thousands of historical artworks are thought to have been trafficked out of Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Adam Hancock
